There was a good thread in 2020 about git commit messages (which has been locked for inactivity). Reopening the subject.

I saw this today (punctuation and capitalization intact):

i changed a number

pile on, folks‚Ä¶

‚ÄúAri got a new linux and is testing to see if the software he installed works (he likes to talk about himself in the third person)‚Äù
One line.

‚ÄúRkfjfkaevert ‚Äúwhoops, forgot javadoc lol‚Äù‚Äù
‚Äúeven MOREEEEEEEE changes‚Äù

I promise we‚Äôve gotten somewhat better at this, but some highlights (lowlights?) from the last few years:

  • ‚ÄúFixed a problem with duct tape‚Äù (whether this was a metaphor has been lost to history)

  • ‚ÄúLiterally two indents in the code‚Äù

  • ‚Äúit builds now‚Äù

  • ‚Äútry fix‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúLOTS OF CHANGES‚Äù

  • ‚Äúthis has merge conflicts‚Äù

  • ‚Äúno message‚Äù

  • ‚Äúfrom tonight‚Äù

  • ‚Äúturret boiz :)‚Äù

  • ‚Äúprepare for tunie‚Äù

Oh I have way too many of these, here are some of our best:

The frequent ‚Äúlast commit of the night‚Äù inevitably followed by ‚Äúoops forgot this‚Äù

‚Äúvery, very bad code‚Äù

‚ÄúI did code‚Äù

‚Äúk‚Äù

‚ÄúCooper added a space‚Äù (this one is from @Cooper3175)

‚ÄúI give up‚Äù

‚Äúso close but its 1am‚Äù

And my personal favorite:
‚ÄúSWERVE WORKS FOR REAL!!!‚Äù

At a previous employer I was working on a project that had been handed over to us from a development team in Poland.

I‚Äôm not joking when I say that the entire Git history looked like this:

Each one essentially translates to ‚Äúchanges‚Äù or ‚Äúfixes‚Äù.
